posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

"Our democracy" (referring to the ostensibly republican governments common to the Western World) is not the political representation of the public good. It is an elitist, cosmopolitan structure in which wealth and opportunism afford greater political authority than willingness to serve the common good. The people in such a system do not have the privilege of choosing what is best for them; they choose what will harm them in the short term to the lesser degree.
Democracy is an excellent ideal - but neither our leaders nor we citizens live up to it.

That is true. It is also true that, at certain times in world history, the process of popular representation- the democratic process - was used to great and good effect. The Glorious Revolution in England, the early USA republic, the Roman Republic - democracy can exist and prolong itself toward the benefit of its constituency. However, democracy is singularly vulnerable to the subversion and usurpation of political authority which is common to vested interests. Put another way, democracies fail if and when someone uses them for the benefit of the few rather than the many.

Pure democracy is a terrible way to run a country but the thing is that the citizenry doesn't need to be 140 IQ people doing CIA detective work on politics, they're not the ones that are actually doing the governing and running the country. That would be whoever they elect. The people just need to choose the better guy most of the time and it'll run fine enough. Voters usually will be swayed by a general sentiment of "I'm/the country isn't doing so well under this guy, so the other one seems better," or the opposite. So if things aren't going well they'll kick the man out. This is preferable to not even having the option to kick a shitty ruler out, except by civil war, which also makes the ruler less accountable in the end because people are going to be less willing to initiate a civil war compared to just voting out a poor leader.
I hear people use the "would you rather have a certified doctor or a random bunch of people perform surgery on you" analogy but really an accurate analogy would be "you are part of a group that will be operated on. Would you rather choose by a majority vote with the group who you would want to operate on all of you, with their qualifications and experience all laid out before you and the doctors given the chance to try to persuade you and debate in front of you why any one of them should be the one to operate? Or would you rather have no choice?" I prefer the first option.

>>14413994
The point of democracy is not that decisions taken by the uninformed majority are better than decisions taken by an informed expert, the point of democracy is separation of powers. It is the only system, in theory, in which the government is constantly scrutinised by legislators and judges, and the government is powerless to send people to jail or act as judge, jury and executioner. In other systems e.g. military dictatorships or absolute monarchies, all powers are concentrated in one person - of course this always depends on the specific case, for example dictator Mussolini was deposed by the legislative Council of Fascism, dictator Pinochet stepped down after losing a referendum, etc but that's the general idea. An absolute monarch is above the law; a feudal lord, a warlord, a sultan not only rules the land but acts as judge and legislator as well. This cannot happen in a democracy, by definition. Rule by majority is a secondary thing.

>>14413363
>Why did Hinduism survive when all other forms of Paganism failed?

I'm under the impression it survived because it had the all the necessary "qualities" of a formal institutionalized religion. By that I mean it had temples, monks, priests, they were writing their own literature (most of Europe's pagan religion and mythology was recorded by Catholics for instance), and when faced with a higher standard of living present in metropolitan life it could still give answers to metaphysical, emotional, existential questions that bother intellectuals. This last part is especially important for endowing a religion with a timeless quality that will persist in the face of modernity. A lot of pagan beliefs didn't survive because they depended on genuine ignorance and worship of the "gods of gaps".
This is pure assumption, but I also think Hinduism had (and still has) the benefit of controlled, slow, exposure to competing foreign religions and getting the opportunity to workshop more. India has something called the Kumhb Mela/Magh Mela every 12 years where hundreds of millions of people show up at the Ganges river to get baptized, seek absolution of sin, and discuss theology. This kind of convening probably allowed Hinduism to acknowledge competing theories and schools of thought, copy their homework, adapt, survive, overcome, etc..

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14413393
I understand, OP.

Consciousness, for me, is the flowering point of the great and wonderful mystery of life and existence.

It is easy enough to imagine an objective reality, operated by physical laws, of which human beings are a part of and thus subject to its laws. This is the implicit worldview that science has-- everything is explainable as derivative from the laws of a purely-material reality.

The mystery of consciousness, however, poses an entirely new problem: how can subjective 'experience', which seems to have 'meaningful' (non-abstract) existence, yet does not appear to be material in nature, exist within the material universe of science?

Assuming science does not prove consciousness/conscious experience to be a material entity (i.e. composed of material building blocks like particles), it seems that science will either have to ignore conscious experience and deal only with behavioral consciousness as a phenomenon (philosophically side-stepping the issue), or to expand the view of material reality to some greater conception of reality that includes the capacity for meaningfully existent, non-abstract, non-material phenomena such as consciousness.

It's a very exciting thought, but I think the hard problem will never be solved. I personally believe in a sort of epistemic pessimism, that the tools of reasoning we possess, by virtue of being extensive from the reality they exist in, will never be able to fully understand or grasp the nature of their reality. I saw somewhere where someone said the hard problem is like "trying to bite your own teeth", which seems the most accurate description of the whole ordeal.

I try to stay optimistic about the problem as a whole, though. This kind of problem means that there will always be an element of mystery to life so long as there are always humans to wonder, and that this element implies the existence of something greater than material reality.

Skull racks were a pretty widespread thing in Mesoamerica, it's not specific to the Aztec even in the broader sense as the Nahua as a whole (rather then the Mexica specifically): For example, a Maya skull rack got found in a cave in Chiapas a few months ago.

As for the purpose of a skull rack, some have argued it's meant to be a statement of power, to keep people in line or to flex military strength since most sacrifical victims were captured enemy soldiers, but it could also be a symbol of piety or even a reminder or mortality not disimilar to Christian ossuaries, since a lot of the symbolism behind sacrifice is meant to be a reflection of life and death's interconnectedness and how even on a cosmic level, the gods sacrificed themselves to create things and sacrifice is paying that debt back. See also themes of mortality in Nahua/Aztec poetry in pic related.

>did they believe the skulls had some magical power source

I'm not sure about the heads, but it is widely understood that the concept of divinity ("Teotl") in Aztec and to an extent other Mesoamerican cultures extended to a wider range of supernatural beings rather then just gods (See Kami in Japanese religion) and to maybe a supernatural force or fabric like Mana in polynesia (but the specific of this and how to interpret it is pretty heavily debated), and part of the reason why cannabalism of sacrificial victims is a thing is because the "main" sacrifices in a given ceremony, the ixiptla, "became" the god they were being sacrificed to, so you're consuming that divine energy/flesh of gods.

>For a settled society, you have greater numbers
Not really. Mobilisation in nomadic societies was roughly some 30% of the population. The only sedentary society to ever achieve such a high rate of mobilisation was the Roman Republic. I think they have a point. Feminism and transgenderism are not really reconcilable if one really thinks about it

The basic, most essential concept of modern feminism is that men and women differ in biology, and in nothing else.
Taking modern feminism to its full conclusion is saying “If you're a doctor, an athlete, or you want to procreate with me, my sex matters. In all other cases, my sex does not matter.”
This means that all other aspects of sex - gender included - are put on people from the outside. Gender roles, “feeling feminine”, “acting like a man” - all of those are creations of society, not something inherent to a person.
This is important. To modern feminism, gender is an external concept. It comes from outside. You are told that you are a man or a woman and because of that you need to behave a certain way, feel certain feelings, have certain hobbies.
The most extreme of feminists believe that gender does not exist. To them, sex exists, and gender is an ilusion.

To most transgender people, the opposite goes. Gender is not external, it is not an illusion; it is a very real, internal concept.
Transgender people know their gender, they feel it to their very core. They are male, female or other - they aren't told they are, they are.
Now, obviously, most transgender people still believe that gender is a social construct, but it is no less real because of it. To them, the concept of gender is not the enemy but its rigidity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The rite of exorcism and chrismation were intimately connected as a single rite with baptism in the early Church. Early Christians thought demons were everywhere and were unclean, in order for God's Spirit to rest in a person he/she needed to be exercised before baptism and then chrismation/laying on of hands. Triple immersion baptism in the name of the Trinity (generally, or a trinity at least) cleanses a person of sin and makes them consubstantial with Christ and in some sense mini-christs who are adopted as God's children. Chrismation and the laying on of the hands imparts the Holy Spirit and his gifts to the elect. Early Christianity was charismatic too not too but eventually the orthodox began to reject gifts because they were being abused. Still, it was not uncommon for some Christians, like the Monatist, to believe God spoke personally through them. Monatists heavily promoted the divinity of the Holy Spirit as God. Gnostics thought their divine angelic counterpart spoke in them. Baptism was a chief sacrament in early Christianity. Some Christians thought ultimate redemption happened at Christ's baptism rather than crucifixion or resurrection. Even still, the Eastern Church places more emphasis on the resurrection in redemption whereas western theologians focus more on the crucifixion itself for redemption. Baptism is a derivative of the Jewish act of immersing in a mikveh, but with a new meaning attached to cleansing sin as a replacement for sacrifice. It was basically invented by John the Baptist himself, not Jesus. Similar ideas appear in the Qumran literature. The role of prayer forms as a replacement for sacrifice in Rabbinical Judaism, notice how both groups lack a temple. Though the notion of prayer also being sacrificial was known at this time. The Jesus sect is a Messianic offshoot of the Jewish Baptist movement, an outgrowth of Essenism.

> How exactly could the Roman legion defeat the Macedonian phalanx? According to ancient texts, it seems the phalanx actually had the upper hand.

Better leadership and troop positioning at crucial engagements.

Thats pretty much it.
Most of pre-modern warfare is basically just this.
People like to pinpoint easy explanations because it makes them feel better, but there was nothing inherently superior in the maniple system to the phalanx, just as there was nothing superior in the germanic/celt shieldwall to the maniple when the Germans/Celts ass blasted the Romans into their greatests defeats ever during the Cimbri/Teuton invasion or any other example of similar Roman defeats or victories.

Similarly, you can just straight up remove any form of troop type and formation on most battles and the outcome probably doesn't change.

You give Surena heavy infantry and foot archers vs Crassus, the Romans still lose Carrhae,
you remove slingers from Publius Ventidius, he still wins those three battles,
you remove horse archers from the entire Mongol army and turn them all into lancers, they still win all those battles.
You remove longbowmen from English army at Crecy, Agincourt, Poitiers and give them medium infantry instead to support those knights and men at arms and they still likely win handidly, because of slope and geography.

It is just leadership and troop positioning mostly.

Hence some Roman armies delivering miserably, and others miraculously, despite being basically the same except hamata/segmentata ratio for some 400 fucking years.

>The continuities between the old and the new agriculture are disguised by the paradoxes of agrarian capitalism. The landscape at the heart of the rural idyll is not the product of a peasant society or a countryside of independent family farms. It is largely the creation of agrarian capitalism in its ‘golden age’. Although it was centuries in the making, and though the marks of other times and other ways of life have never been completely erased, the landscape that figures most prominently in the mythology of ‘England’s green and pleasant land’ probably owes more to the eighteenth century than any other, ‘the age of the territorial aristocracy’ and the era of ‘improvement’ at its height.1
>The seemingly idyllic landscape of rural England has inscribed within it the history of capitalist property and class relations. Both peasants and landlords underwent a transformation, which changed the landscape too. On one side is the process of dispossession and enclosure, which, among other things, made rural poverty less visible. Poor peasants of the type that have shaped the countryside in other agricultural societies, with their marginal plots and impoverished dwellings, were replaced by two distinct agrarian classes: more prosperous capitalist tenants, with their solid, even picturesque farmhouses, and landless labourers, whose only mark on the landscape was a system of rights-of-way across fields giving them access to their places of work – their gift to ramblers today. Even whole villages disappeared in this process of rural transformation. On the other side are country houses, parks, and landscape gardens. The remains of a classic military aristocrary had long been replaced by the comforts and ornaments of the country gentleman, the ‘territorial aristocrat’ living on the rents of capitalist tenants, who truly came into his own in the eighteenth century.

>sodoku ginmi standardized the kundoku reading, which converts the syntactical order of the kanbun to “Japanese-local” grammar by inserting diacritical marks, particles, and suffixes, and conjugating words as necessary. The focus on the kundoku emerged out of an anti-Ogyū Sorai movement, as Sorai, in his “discovery” of the ancient texts, criticized the kundoku as “a barrier that stood between the reader and the language of Confucian texts,” suggesting that “the ancient way” could only be accessed through chokudoku (literally “direct reading,” referring to a reading in pure kanbun syntax) via kaon (in the “original” sound). In criticizing such a view, Neo-Confucian scholars tried to show that it was in fact in the kundoku that “accurate” reading could be offered. What sodoku ginmi did, in other words, was to disseminate and standardize the kundoku form of reading. What is important to remember, then, is that this institutionalized practice of reading, the core of kangaku study, was the orality of kundoku reading.
>As we shall see in the following chapter, the competing “languages” that were foregrounded through these “sounds” continued to shape the calls for reform in the 1880s, which were marked by the emergence of kanbun kundokutai as “common language.” An inquiry into kanbun kundokutai will not only allow us to reassess the role of kan in the production of linguistic modernity, but also to see how the “languages” changed form as linguistic reforms entered a new era with the appearance of a “common language.”

posts.com: It is a mistake to treat religion as a constant in human culture across time and space. Ancient languages have no word that approximates what modern English speakers mean by religion; Wilfred Cantwell Smith cites the scholarly consensus that neither the Greeks nor the Egyptians had any equivalent term for religion, and he adds that a similar negative conclusion is found for the Aztecs and the ancient civilizations of India, China, and Japan. The word is derived from the ancient Latin word religio, but religio was only one of a constellation of terms surrounding social obligations in ancient Rome, and when used it signified something quite different from religion in the modern sense. Religio referred to a powerful requirement to perform some action. Its most probable derivation is from re-ligare, to rebind or relink, that is, to reestablish a bond that has been severed. To say religio mihi est—that something is “religio for me”—meant that it was something that carried a serious obligation for a person. This included not only cultic observances—which were themselves sometimes referred to as religiones, such that there was a different religio or set of observances at each shrine—but also civic oaths and family rituals, things that modern Westerners normally consider to be secular. When religio did refer to temple sacrifices, it was possible—and common among certain intellectuals—in ancient Rome to practice religio, but not believe in the existence of gods. Although Cicero’s De Natura Deorum puts forth naturalistic social and psychological theories for the origin of belief in gods, Cicero himself was a priest, and retained his position on the Board of Augurs of the republic. reli- gio was largely indifferent to theological doctrine and was about the customs and traditions that provided the glue for the Roman social order.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For a society as open as Kerala once was, breasts came to provoke a grave panic in the Victorian age. This was the land where Portuguese merchants in the sixteenth century beheld bare-breasted princesses negotiating treaties of trade and leading bare-chested troops in battle. It was here that a seventeenth-century Italian found himself in the court of a prince, packed with royal women covered only around the waist—two young nieces of the ruler wondered with amusement why on earth the visitor was so covered up in the tropical heat. This was also the land where women enjoyed physical and sexual autonomy, where widowhood was no calamity and one husband could always be replaced with another. The coast was rich with tales of great women—from Unniarcha of the northern ballad of Malabar, an accomplished warrior from Nangeli’s caste, to Umayamma of Attingal, a princess who reigned over kings. These were brave women of towering personality. But in the nineteenth century, Kerala’s moral conscience grappled not with their achievements as much as the conundrum that their unabashed bare-breastedness presented.
Virtue, as we recognise it today in its patriarchal definition, was not a concept that existed in Kerala. And till our colonial masters—and fellow Indians from patriarchal backgrounds—sat in judgement over the matrilineal streak heavily infused among the dominant groups here, women, their bare torsos and their sexual freedoms did not in the least attract attention or odium. Where elsewhere polygamy was a practice available to men, in Kerala there was polyandry on offer, because women were not unequal to their brothers (or, to be more exact, they were less unequal). They owned property and controlled resources, living fuller lives than the domesticated child-rearing destinies ordained to their sisters elsewhere. But this was, of course, the case of women of privilege.

The advent of the British meant more than just a new political order; they brought to Kerala a new sense of morality, reinforced by missionaries who had the ear of these foreign masters. Polyandrous marriage was deemed ‘very revolting’—women were told that they ought to be virtuous, which meant deference to one husband, one master. They had to cultivate modesty, and toplessness was not a step in that direction. The sexual gaze of the patriarchal Victorian was turned towards the breast in Kerala, till then not a cause of concern. When men and women entered temples, they both took off their top cloth. Today only the men are obliged to do this.
But the import of Victorian patriarchy also imported shame, and women were told that a bare body was a mark of disgrace. Dignity lay in accepting male objectification; honour was located in docility. Men, studying in colleges in big cities, received jibes about their topless mothers who may have had more than one husband. Could they ever be sure about who their fathers were? These men dragged into Kerala the masculinity of their patriarchal interlocutors, and women too, exposed to the West and a new conception of femininity, succumbed. ‘We will publish nothing related to politics,’ declared one of the region’s earliest women’s magazines in 1892, adding that ‘writings that energise the moral conscience’—tips on cooking, stories of ‘ideal women’—and ‘other such enlightening topics’ alone would be covered. A lady’s job was in the home as a mother, as a loyal wife and housekeeper, not outside as a topless harlot who exercised her customary right to divorce. ‘As women,’ another declaration went, ‘our god-ordained duty is the care of the home and service towards our husbands.’

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In the Western philosophical tradition, it was usual, until recent times, to ask: does knowledge arise from *reason* or from *experience*? The rationalists and the empiricists differed in their answers. These answers, in their various formulations, determined the course of Western philosophy. In the Sanksrit philosophical vocabulary, the words 'reason' and 'experience' have no exact synonyms, and the epistemological issue was never formulated in such general terms. On the other hand, a question which was asked is: is perception [pratyakṣa] the only pramāṇa or is anumāna [inference] a pramāṇa? Neither is 'perception' synonymous with 'experience', nor '*anumāna*' with 'reason'. Those who recognize perception as *pramāṇa* (in fact, every philosophical school did so) often did not restrict perception to sensory perception, and did not restrict sensory perception to the domain of sensible qualities, such as color, and material objects, such as sticks and stones. Among things that were taken to be sensuously perceived are: the self and its qualities, such as pleasure, pain, desire and cognition; universals, such as redness; natural-kind essences, such as cowness; and relations, such as contact and inherence (of a quality in a substance; of a universal in its instances). That *anumāna* or inference is different from reason (of the rationalists) is clear from its very etymology; it follows upon perception. If we leave the Buddhists out, no school of Indian philosophy ascribed to inference a 'constructive' role. It knows what can be known otherwise. There is always a priority of perception. There are no Indian rationalists. Neither perception nor inference pointed to any specific faculty of the mind—as 'experience' and 'reason' did in classical Western philosophies. The same faculties or cognitive instruments—operating in different manners–resulted in one case in perception, in another in inference.

There's a lesser known parable in classical Indian philosophy known as “Menander’s Chariot” (which is a similar but better formulation of the famous parable of Theseus’ ship). The Milinda Pañha (“Questions of King Menander”) portrays a dialogue between King Menander and the monk Nāgasena. Since attaining canonical form in Plutarch as Theseus’ ship, a version of this thought experiment has had a long life in European philosophical thought, where it is often used to argue for some version of mereological nihilism. But the Milinda Pañha has a different conclusion. First, it suggests that the chariot is only provisionally or conventionally the same chariot. Any entity composed of parts or aggregates lacks a single or essential nature. So in this respect, a process is in some sense always changing, and therefore lacks autonomous or permanent identity (again, think of Heraclitus never stepping in the same river). This seems to be a largely skeptical response. But the Milinda Pañha goes one step further, and suggests that the conventional identity of the chariot is similar to a lit torch being used to light another torch. Is it the same flame? No. But Nāgasena argues that the flames share a causal continuity. Restated, whatever the degree to which Menander’s chariot is the same chariot, it is the same because it shares a process or causal continuity. You are not the matter of your body, but to the extent that you are provisionally you, you are an unfolding process with a particular causal history.

It wasn't really sudden, the number of executions had been in decline since the 50's, and there hadn't been a single execution in 4 years when it was abolished in 1981. Francois Mitterrand's justice minister was a criminal defense attorney who had actually defended the last person executed, and was a very vocal critic of the death penalty. posts.com:
One of the big blunders of Nixon's '60 campaign was the questionable choice of Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. as his running mate. Making a speech in Harlem on September 12, Lodge promised that Nixon would "absolutely" include a black member of his cabinet. He did so without consulting or asking the vice president, who was not happy to hear it. Black voters felt insulted and pandered to, and white Southern voters were offended.

Lodge stood in sharp contract to Lyndon Johnson, who went on a barnstorming campaign through the South, casting himself as (depending on who he was speaking to) a humble rancher, the grandson of a Confederate soldier, the black man's friend, the defender of Dixie's traditional values, and the spoilsman who would bring home pork to his constituents. Lodge for comparison seemed lazy and apathetic; a Boston Brahmin who acted like campaigning was beneath him and he was also surrounded by Boston friends who predicted defeat. At one point, Nixon was aghast to read out a speech Lodge had penned. "It was a concession speech," he recalled.

Nixon would later say picking Lodge was one of his worst mistakes and he should have chosen Kentucky Senator Thruston Morton, a vigorous campaigner who could have matched LBJ's appeal to the South.
